276.8: Hypokalemia: Foods rich in potassium: dried fruits (particularly apricots and figs), nuts, bran cereals, wheat germ, lima beans, molasses, leafy green vegetables, broccoli, winter squash, beets, carrots, cauliflower, potatoes, avocados, tomatoes, coconut water, citrus fruits (oranges), cantaloupe, kiwis, mangoes, bananas, red meats.
Mild hypokalemia (>3.0 mEq/L) treatment with potassium chloride supplements taken by mouth, either in tablet or syrup form.
Potassium bicarbonate for hypokalemia associated with metabolic acidosis.
Severe hypokalemia (<3.0 mEq/L) treatment via IV supplementation typically using a saline solution with 20–40 meq/L KCl per liter over 3–4 hours.
Use of central venous catheter for solutions containing high concentrations of potassium (>40 mmol/L).
In cases of recurrent or treatment-resistant hypokalemia, medications such as amiloride, triamterene, spironolactone, or eplerenone might be used.
Necessary when hypokalemia persists despite potassium supplementation, as magnesium is a cofactor for potassium uptake.
Treatment includes stopping offending medications, treating underlying medical conditions, and managing other electrolyte abnormalities.
277.39: Amyloidosis: High-dose melphalan followed by stem cell transplantation (for early-stage AL amyloidosis)
Chemotherapy including cyclophosphamide-bortezomib-dexamethasone (for AL amyloidosis not eligible for transplant)
Tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha inhibitors such as infliximab and etanercept (for AA amyloidosis with inflammation)

Soda water/sparkling water (also a zero-calorie beverage)

285.1: Acute posthemorrhagic anemia: Immediate blood transfusion to replace lost blood volume and hemoglobin
Intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure and volume while preparing for blood transfusion
Oxygen therapy to ensure adequate oxygenation of tissues
Iron supplementation to help the body replenish red blood cells after acute blood loss
Monitoring and treatment of potential coagulopathy (bleeding disorder) if present
Surgical or interventional procedures to control ongoing bleeding if the source is identifiable and accessible

285.21: Chronic kidney disease: Loop diuretics (for edema and additional blood pressure control)

Staying active and certain dietary changes

Controlled tapering off of the precipitating substance using similarly acting compounds

Administration of benzodiazepines to achieve light sedation
Adjunctive non-benzodiazepine medications for sleep disturbance
Haloperidol (as a major tranquilizer to combat overactivity)

Treatment of any associated electrolyte abnormalities
Addressing possible underlying conditions such as pancreatitis or alcoholic hepatitis
Treatment for status epilepticus, if it occurs
Well-lit room provision to help alleviate hallucinations

291.81: Alcohol withdrawal syndrome: Naltrexone, acamprosate, and disulfiram (for prevention of further drinking, post-withdrawal)

Cognitive behavior techniques for kleptomania, including covert sensitization, imaginal desensitization, systematic desensitization, aversion therapy, relaxation training, and seeking alternative sources of satisfaction
Cognitive behavior therapy techniques for compulsive buying, including exposure and response prevention, relapse prevention, cognitive restructuring, covert sensitization, and stimulus control

Dialysis for severe cases (e.g., uremic encephalopathy)

Prescription of anticonvulsants for seizure reduction or control

Lifelong abstinence from alcohol (in the case of alcohol-induced toxic encephalopathy)

357.2: Polyneuropathy: Ascertain and manage the underlying cause
Blood pressure control, especially for those with diabetes
Intravenous immunoglobulin, used for multifocal motor neuropathy and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)
Methylprednisolone, indicated as a viable treatment for CIDP
Avoidance or limitation of corticosteroids in the treatment of critical illness polyneuropathy
357.82: Critical illness polyneuropathy: Minimizing the use of potential contributory drugs: Avoiding or carefully using certain medications such as corticosteroids and neuromuscular blocking agents, which may contribute to the development of CIP and CIM.

Physiotherapy and rehabilitation: Early mobilization and physical therapy help prevent muscle atrophy due to prolonged immobilization and may improve recovery.
Optimization of nutrition: Ensuring adequate nutritional support to address the catabolic state that critically ill patients often experience.

Pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (PTE - a surgical procedure to remove an organized thrombus from the pulmonary artery)
411.1: Angioplasty: Atherectomy (occasionally used in conjunction with peripheral angioplasty)
Renal artery angioplasty, with or without stenting

Performing surgical anastomosis to bypass narrowings

Possible use of right internal mammary artery, radial artery, or great saphenous vein
Off-pump coronary artery bypass graft (OPCABG)
Anastomoses constructed while the heart is beating
Use of techniques to stabilize the heart during the procedure

Preoperative examination and strategy development

Stopping certain medications (e.g., anticoagulants) to prevent bleeding

Revascularization with saphenous veins
Use of alternative arterial grafts
Exploring grafts from other arteries when ITAs are not an option

Monitoring and management in ICU
Recommendation of tailored exercise plans after discharge
Long-term patient management

Continued medical management for cardiovascular risk reduction
Comparative approaches
CABG vs. Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) in certain patient populations

Expectorants (to help clear mucus from the lungs)

424.1: Valvular heart disease: Avoidance of smoking and excessive alcohol consumption

Diuretics (to treat pulmonary congestion or edema)

Heart failure management with digoxin, diuretics, nitrovasodilators, and ACE inhibitors (if not contraindicated)
Aortic valve replacement (for severe symptomatic aortic regurgitation or evidence of left ventricular dysfunction)
Treatment of hypertension with calcium channel blockers, ACE inhibitors, or ARBs
Endocarditis prophylaxis for at-risk procedures
Percutaneous balloon mitral valvuloplasty (PBMV) (for symptomatic severe mitral stenosis)
Mitral valve surgery (if PBMV fails or is not feasible, may include valve replacement, repair, or commissurotomy)

Immediate cardioversion, preferably with a biphasic DC shock of 200 joules
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation for those in cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia
Precordial thump (reserved for those with prior experience) for witnessed unstable ventricular tachycardia while on a heart monitor

Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem, verapamil)

Monitoring and evaluation through clinical prediction rules and cardiopulmonary exercise testing
428.32: Heart failure with preserved eje: Treatment aimed at symptom relief and management of comorbid conditions

Management of commonly associated conditions such as atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia

Self-expanding devices that attach to the external surface of the left ventricle (ImCardia and CORolla TAA under investigation)
428.33: Acute decompensated heart failur: Oxygen Administration: Supplemental oxygen for low blood oxygen levels; not recommended for routine use.
Diuretics: Intravenous loop diuretics like furosemide; in cases of diuretic resistance, use of bumetanide, possibly combined with thiazide diuretics such as metolazone or chlorothiazide.
Nitrates such as nitroglycerin and isosorbide dinitrate for initial therapy.
Nesiritide with caution and only if conventional therapy is ineffective or contraindicated.
ACE inhibitors: Used with caution and not initiated during acute decompensation, particularly in individuals with poor kidney perfusion.
Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs): Similar caution as ACE inhibitors in the context of acute decompensation.
Beta-blockers: They may be decreased or stopped in cases of low blood pressure.
Inotropic Agents: Used in cases of low blood pressure (SBP < 90 mmHg) to support cardiac output.
Opioids: Historically used for acute pulmonary edema but not commonly recommended due to lack of supporting evidence.
Morphine: Though mentioned, there's no affirmation of its use in the treatment in the text provided.
Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV): Including continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for improving symptoms and potentially reducing mortality.
Mechanical Ventilation: For severe respiratory failure requiring endotracheal intubation.
Ultrafiltration: For fluid removal in ADHF patients with kidney failure, particularly to reduce long-term hospitalization rate.

Surgical Intervention: In cases of acute aortic regurgitation, ventricular aneurysm rupture, and cardiac tamponade, and for heart valve repair/replacement, coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), or heart transplantation.
Angioplasty: To improve symptoms of coronary artery disease (CAD) and reduce damage post-heart attack.
Pacemakers: To treat abnormal heart rhythms contributing to heart failure.
430: Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Prompt neurosurgery or endovascular coiling
Medications such as labetalol to lower blood pressure
Treatment of fevers
Use of Nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker, to prevent vasospasm

External ventricular drain (EVD) placement in certain cases
Maintaining systolic blood pressure between 140 and 160 mmHg

Clipping or coiling to reduce the risk of rebleeding from a cerebral aneurysm

Transcranial Doppler screening for vasospasm development
Treatment with a "triple H" protocol (hypertension, hypervolemia, hemodilution) for symptomatic vasospasm

Therapeutic lumbar puncture or ventricular drain to relieve acute hydrocephalus
Prevention of deep vein thrombosis with compression stockings or intermittent pneumatic compression
Pain management with non-sedating agents like codeine
Prevention of complications such as pneumonia, cardiac decompensation, and electrolyte imbalance
Nutritional support preferably via mouth or nasogastric tube
Use of bladder catheter for fluid balance monitoring
Possible benzodiazepines for distress
Administration of antiemetic drugs to manage vomiting
Prophylactic antiepileptic medications for seizure prevention, although use is controversial
431: Intracerebral hemorrhage: Care in an intensive care unit
Strict blood pressure control with frequent use of both pressors and antihypertensive agents
Maintenance of normal blood sugar levels
Possible placement of an external ventricular drain
Surgical removal of the blood if indicated
Rapid lowering of blood pressure using antihypertensive therapy
Administration of Factor VIIa within 4 hours to limit bleeding (with consideration of thromboembolism risks)
Administration of frozen plasma, vitamin K, protamine, or platelet transfusions in case of coagulopathy
Use of specific reversal agents such as idarucizumab and andexanet alfa for patients on direct oral anticoagulants, or prothrombin complex concentrate if specific agents are not available
Anticonvulsant administration reserved for those with clinical seizures or seizure activity on EEG
Administration of H2 antagonists or proton pump inhibitors for stress ulcer prevention
Surgical interventions such as aspiration by stereotactic surgery, endoscopic drainage, or craniectomy depending on hematoma size, location, and patient condition

Craniotomy for large or symptomatic hematomas to open the skull, remove the clot, and control bleeding

Conservative medication treatment for chronic subdural hematoma, which may include:

437.0: Cerebral atherosclerosis: Over-the-counter platelet inhibitors like aspirin for asymptomatic individuals with intracranial stenosis

Bypass surgery of the blocked area
458.29: Cerebrospinal fluid leak: Increased caffeine intake (either orally or intravenous caffeine infusion)
Use of an abdominal binder to increase intracranial pressure temporarily
Injection of the patient's own blood at the site of the CSF leak
An initial lumbar epidural blood patch can often provide relief
Placement of percutaneous fibrin glue to form a clot and arrest the leakage
Neurosurgical repair to directly repair leaking meningeal diverticula
Ligation of the areas of dura leak and placement of a metal clip
Pledget placement over the dura leak sealed with gel foam and fibrin glue
Use of a surgical lumbar drain to decrease spinal CSF volume and increase intracranial CSF pressure
Antibiotics to prevent meningitis (unclear benefit when due to skull fracture)
Symptomatic treatment like mentioned conservative treatments may continue after surgical interventions to assist in recovery.
Tetracosactide (corticotropin) to stimulate additional CSF production
Epidural saline infusion to temporarily restore CSF volume
Intrathecal saline infusion for urgent cases such as intractable pain or decreased consciousness
482.9: Bacterial pneumonia: Antibiotics (general, not specific to any organism)
Rifampicin (in combination with erythromycin for Legionella pneumophila)

Vaccination against Haemophilus influenzae type B, meningococcus, Bordetella pertussis, Bacillus anthracis, and Yersinia pestis
491.21: Acute bronchitis: Paracetamol (acetaminophen) for fever and pain relief
Avoidance of smoking and lung irritants
Increase fluid intake to stay well hydrated
Cough medicines (though limited support for use and not recommended for children under six years of age)
Honey and pelargonium (tentative evidence supports use to help with symptoms)
Inhaled bronchodilators like salbutamol for adults with wheezing due to restricted airways (weak evidence; can lead to nervousness, shakiness, or tremor)

Smoking cessation to aid healing of the bronchial tree
491.8: Bronchitis: Salbutamol for wheezing (may cause nervousness and tremors)
Honey and pelargonium (to help with symptoms)
Antibiotics (generally not recommended unless for pertussis infections)
Mucolytics (e.g. guaifenesin and erdosteine to decrease exacerbations)
Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor (e.g. roflumilast for significant exacerbations)

511.9: Pleural effusion: Therapeutic aspiration: Sometimes removing a sample of fluid is also therapeutic.

Chemical pleurodesis: Agents like talc, bleomycin, tetracycline, or doxycycline are used to scar pleural surfaces together.

Antituberculosis treatment (ATT): For tubercular pleural effusion, typically involves an initial course of isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide, followed by a continuation phase with isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol.
518.0: Pulmonary embolism: Thrombolysis using medications such as tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
Vena cava filter (if blood thinners are not appropriate)

Moving as soon as possible after surgery
518.5: Pulmonary contusion: Supportive Care
Monitoring of fluid balance, respiratory function, and oxygen saturation with pulse oximetry
Watching for complications such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
Ensuring adequate blood oxygenation
Use of supplemental oxygen, potentially warmed and humidified
May use extracorporeal membranous oxygenation (ECMO) in severe cases
Ventilation
Administering noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (CPAP or BiPAP) if oxygenation is significantly impaired
Applying mechanical ventilation if necessary, potentially with higher pressures for reopened collapsed alveoli
Use of invasive positive pressure ventilation with intubation and mechanical ventilators for individuals with inadequate respiration or oxygenation
Considering early intubation in anticipation of respiratory compromise
Implementation of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to keep alveoli from collapsing and reducing edema
Fluid Therapy
Administering fluid with caution to ensure adequate blood volume while avoiding fluid overload and exacerbation of pulmonary edema

Placement of a pulmonary artery catheter for monitoring pulmonary artery pressure in individuals requiring significant intravenous fluid
Supportive Care
Engaging in pulmonary toilet with suction, deep breathing, coughing, and other methods to keep airways clear
Performing chest physical therapy to remove lung secretions and expand collapsed lung areas
Positioning patients to improve oxygenation, with the uninjured lung lower than the injured one
Preventing and addressing infections with antibiotics, as appropriate
Managing pain with analgesics or nerve blockade to facilitate coughing and prevent hypoventilation
518.83: Respiratory failure: Naloxone (for opioid overdose, has an antidote)
Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation (if severe)
Mechanical ventilation (if NIV fails or is indicated immediately)
Continuous positive airway pressure initiated before conveyance to hospital (tentative evidence of benefit)
519.4: Pelvic floor: Pelvic floor exercises (PFE), also known as Kegel exercises

Estimating pelvic floor muscle tone with a perineometer
Surgical repair of pelvic floor muscles

530.81: Gastroesophageal reflux disease: Lifestyle changes:
Not lying down for three hours after eating
Lying down on the left side
Raising the pillow or bedhead height
Losing weight
Stopping smoking
Avoiding foods that may precipitate GERD (coffee, alcohol, chocolate, fatty foods, acidic foods, and spicy foods)

V85.39: Body mass index: First, it is important to note that Body Mass Index (BMI) itself is an index for assessing body weight relative to a person\'s height, not a condition that is treated. The treatments referenced in this text would relate to health conditions that might be associated with being underweight, overweight, or obese, as inferred by BMI values. There are no direct "treatments for BMI" indicated in the text. Rather, it discusses managing the conditions associated with abnormal BMI values. Lifestyle modifications, including changes in diet and increased physical activity, to manage body weight.

Corticosteroid treatment for women who might deliver between 24 and 37 weeks (to improve outcomes)
Medications such as nifedipine (to delay delivery)
Keeping the baby warm through skin-to-skin contact or incubation

Medications to delay delivery: Such as nifedipine, to allow time for the mother to be transferred to a specialized medical center and for corticosteroids to work.

Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP): To maintain lung volumes during respiratory distress syndrome.

Kangaroo care to promote warmth and breastfeeding
Parenteral nutrition for adequate hydration and nutrition

765.17: Preterm birth: Nifedipine (and other medications to delay labor)
Medical care once the baby is born
Support for breastfeeding and/or formula feeding
To treat infections and reduce group B streptococcus-related mortality
Medications to delay delivery for short-term benefits (24–48 hours)

Harvesting of arteries or veins from other parts of the body:
Use of the left internal mammary artery (LIMA), also known as the left internal thoracic artery (LITA), for grafting.
Use of the right internal mammary artery (RIMA) for grafting.
Use of the radial artery for grafting.
Use of the great saphenous vein for grafting.
Surgical anastomosis construction: connecting harvested arteries and veins across areas of narrowing in heart arteries.
Temporary arrest of the heart during on-pump CABG: using a cardioplegic solution that is rich in potassium.
Revascularization in emergency cases: may involve the use of intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) and rapid establishment of cardiopulmonary bypass.
Minimally invasive direct coronary artery bypass (MIDCAB): avoids large incision in the sternum, and may be performed off-pump through a small incision or with robotic assistance.

Attention to maternal nutrition to prevent potential impacts on offspring’s stress sensitivity, sperm quality, and cardiac energy metabolism.
